Size control of Pt nanoparticle catalysts for high-selectivity hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to p-aminophenol Feng Feng Conceptualization Yaoyao Zhen Writing – original draft Yixin Chen Methodology Data curation Jie Luo Supervision Chong Yao Supervision Limei Pan Data curation Ruihao Chen Data curation Jiwei Wu Data curation Chunshan Lu Conceptualization Xiaoliang Xu Conceptualization Qingtao Wang Writing – review & editing Resources Conceptualization ⁎ Qunfeng Zhang Supervision Resources Conceptualization ⁎ Xiaonian Li Supervision Resources Conceptualization ⁎ Institute of Industrial Catalysis of Zhejiang University of Technology, State Key Laboratory, Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology, Hangzhou 310014, P R China Institute of Industrial Catalysis of Zhejiang University of Technology State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology Hangzhou 310014 P R China Institute of Industrial Catalysis of Zhejiang University of Technology, State Key Laboratory, Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology, Hangzhou 310014, P R China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Liquid-phase hydrogenation reaction of nitrobenzene to p-aminophenol (PAP) is investigated using a series of Pt-based catalysts, where activated carbon served as support and ethylene glycol (EG) as the reducing agent and solvent. Different platinum sources are employed to obtain Pt/C catalysts with different Pt metal particle sizes, as determined by transmission electron microscopy. The underlying mechanism of nitrobenzene selective hydrogenation on different size of Pt clusters have been systematically investigated. Characterization and catalytic tests show that the catalytic performance of the Pt-based catalyst is deeply influenced by particle size, where the size around 2.5 nm exhibits a suitable hydrogen absorption and activation ability, leading to the best catalytic performance. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the PAP selectivity reached 76.4 % and the conversion of NB reached 100 %. Moreover, the catalyst displayed strong recyclability with the PAP selectivity remaining above 70 % after five cycles of the catalyst, which would enable promising industrial applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrobenzene hydrogenation Pt catalysts Size effect Thermal reduction method Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction p-Aminophenol (PAP) is an important chemical intermediate and industrial raw material, widely used in the pharmaceutical, pesticide, and dye industries [1–4]. The one-step catalytic hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to PAP is a low-cost, high-yield, and clean process, which is currently recognized as one of the best routes for PAP synthesis [5–7]. In this route, nitrobenzene is first hydrogenated to phenylhydroxylamine (PHA) via nitrosobenzene intermediate and then undergoes Bamberger rearrangement in acidic conditions to generate PAP. However, PHA can also be further hydrogenated to aniline (AN), as shown in Scheme 1 , which is the main byproduct [8–12]. One of the most critical challenges for this route is to choose a suitable material to improve PAP production. Supported noble metal catalysts, including Pt, Pd, Au, etc., are commonly used in the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to PAP [13–17]. Among them, Pt-based catalysts, usually on activated carbon (AC) as support, have been extensively studied in nitrobenzene hydrogenation in the past thirty years because of their high activity [18–21]. However, the comparable desorption and hydrogenation barrier of the intermediate PHA on Pt active sites induce poor PAP selectivity, which hindering the large-scale production of PAP through this economy and environmental hydrogenation process [7]. Therefore, how to improve the selectivity of PAP and suppress over-hydrogenation path is the key issue. Recent studies reveal that the PAP selectivity depends on the catalyst's adsorption capacity for the intermediate PHA [22]. According to previous research, when a catalyst has a weak adsorption ability for PHA, the rearrangement of PHA to PAP is favored [23,24]. To address the selectivity issue of PAP, Liu's group [24] synthesized highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles on phosphorus-doped activated carbon (Pt/P‒ACC). The found that the interaction between platinum and phosphorus endows the platinum surface electron-rich property, reducing the adsorption of electron-rich substrates (i.e., phenylhydroxylamine), thus preventing their over-hydrogenation and enhancing the selectivity of PAP. Gao's group [25] synthesized Pt-Co bimetallic catalysts supported on Y zeolite at different temperatures. The experimental results showed that the introduction of the second metal could reduce the grain size and smaller particle size with excellent dispersion were beneficial for improving the catalytic activity and selectivity. However, the catalytic stability is poor, after one cycle, the selectivity decreased from 74 % to 63 %. Recently, Giovanni et al. [26] discussed the relationship between metal particle size and catalytic activity and found that the catalytic activity and selectivity of intermediate products in the reaction strongly depend on the size of the metal particles. By controlling the concentration of H2PtCl6 precursor solution, Wang et al. [27] found that the size of Pt particles can be controlled and evenly dispersed. As the Pt particle size decreases, the adsorption capacity of the metal active sites for phenylhydroxylamine decreases, which slows down the rate of the deep hydrogenation of phenylhydroxylamine to aniline, thus effectively improving the competition between the rearrangement reaction and the deep hydrogenation side reaction, resulting in improved selectivity of PAP [28–31]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the relationship between particle size effect generated by Pt metal and catalytic reactivity in the nitrobenzene hydrogenation reaction has not been thoroughly investigated. In order to study the underlying mechanism of liquid-phase hydrogenation reaction of nitrobenzene to p-aminophenol at a molecular level on different sizes of Pt catalysts, different precursors (Pt(acac)2,H2PtCl6,Pt(NO3)2,K2PtCl4) were used to synthesize the Pt/AC catalysts by thermal reduction method. The proposed stages in the synthesis of metal nanoparticles, including the supplied atoms from precursors (stage I), nucleation (stage II), and seeds growth (stage III) [32]. It is fully feasible to synthesize nanoparticles simultaneously with monodisperse size and surface structure through ligand-controlled nucleation and growth. The different ligands in these Pt-based precursors can regulate the nucleation, growth and fixation of metal sites during the pyrolysis process, thus contributing to Pt nanoparticles with various size and dispersity. Because ligands can influence the decomposition temperature of the corresponding metal precursor, thus regulating the nucleation rate, growth state and fixed position of metal sites during the pyrolysis process, and finally contributing to Pt nanoparticles with different size and dispersion [33,34]. The particle size and surface crystal morphology of nanoparticles can be controlled by changing the precursor type. The optimized Pt/AC catalysts exhibit improved selectivity and stability in the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene while maintaining good activity and conversion rate. The as-prepared Pt/AC catalysts are characterized by XRD (X-ray diffraction), IR (infrared spectrum), XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy), H2-TPD (H2 temperature-programmed desorption) to analyze the physical and chemical properties, then the correlation between the Pt particle size and catalytic performance (especially selectivity) are thoroughly studied. Additionally, the possible reaction mechanisms are discussed. It is expected that the results can provide a good clue for designing the suitable particle size of highly efficient Pt catalysts in liquid-phase nitrobenzene hydrogenation to p-aminophenol. Experimental Reagents and equipment The reagents used for the synthesis of catalysts include cetyltrimethylammonium chloride (C19H42ClN AR Sinopharm) chloroplatinic acid (H2Cl6Pt AR Aladdin) tetra-chloroplatinic acid (Cl4K2Pt AR) platinum acetylacetonate (C10H14O4Pt AR Aladdin) platinum nitrate (N2O6Pt AR Aladdin). Reagents required for catalyst evaluation include nitrobenzene (C6H5NO2, 99 %, Macklin), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 95 %−98 %, Sino-pharm), cetyltrimethylammonium chloride (CTAC, 97 %, Macklin), p-aminophenol (C6H7NO, ≥98 %, HPLC, Macklin), aniline (C6H7N, ≥99.9 %, GC, Sinopharm), 4,4′-diamino-diphenyl ether (C12H12N2O, 98 %, Macklin), o-aminophenol (C6H7NO, 98 %, Sinopharm). Catalyst preparation Pt/C catalysts were synthesized by a simple thermal reduction method. In a typical experiment, 30 mL of ethylene glycol solvent was first added to a 50 mL three-necked flask, then 0.5 g of activated carbon (pretreated in an oven at 110 °C for 10 h to remove water) and appropriate amounts of Pt precursor (Pt(acac)2, H2PtCl6, K2PtCl4, and Pt (NO3)2) were added to the three-necked flask in turn. The prepared solution was stirred at 150 ℃ for 4 h. After reaction, the resulting solution was filtered and purified with deionized water and ethanol under negative pressure. Finally, the mixture was dried at 60 °C for 8 h in a vacuum oven to obtain a series of Pt/AC catalysts, which were recorded as 3 % Pt/AC‒1, 3 % Pt/AC‒2, 3 % Pt/AC‒3, and 3 % Pt/AC‒4, respectively and representatived Pt(acac)2, H2PtCl6, K2PtCl4, and Pt (NO3)2, orderly. Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscope (TEM) observed the morphology of the catalyst, The instrument model is Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin from FEI, Netherlands, operating at 300 kV. A small amount of powder catalyst is added to anhydrous ethanol for ultrasonic treatment to disperse the sample evenly. An appropriate amount of ethanol solution containing the sample is dabbed on the copper sheet with a capillary tube, and the ethanol is evaporated for electron microscope analysis. The ICP-AES analysis is performed using Agilent's Agilent 7800 instrument. The sample is digested by microwave, the digestion solution is fixed to a certain volume, and finally, the sample is tested. Elemental analysis of C, H, N, and S is carried out with an elemental analyzer (Vario EL, Germany). The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images are recorded by a Hitachi S-4700 scanning electron microscope, and the surface morphology of the samples is analyzed by SEM at an operating accelerating voltage of 15 kV. The catalysts are analyzed by energy dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX). The composition of the samples is detected using a Thermo NORAN-type energy spectrometer manufactured by Thermo Electron Corporation, USA. The catalyst was analyzed using a Vertex 70 V infrared spectrometer produced by Brook Company. First, the infrared spectrum of Pt/AC catalyst was collected in an Ar atmosphere and the background was subtracted. XPS measured the elemental composition of the catalyst surface and the chemical state of the elements. The XPS characterization was performed on a Kratos AXOS Ultra DLD, using an Al Kα-ray excitation source (hν = 1486.6 eV) and an operating current of 3 mA. The binding energy of the sample peaks was corrected by the C 1 s peak (B.E. = 284.8 eV). The Pt4f peaks were deconvoluted with the spin–orbit splitting of 3.45 eV and 4:3 spin–orbit splitting ratios using XPSPeak4.1 software. H2-TPD is performed on a VDSorb-91i-MS chemisorption analyzer, model VDSorb, manufactured by Ward Instruments, using H2 as the probe molecule. Typically, a 50 mg sample is first pretreated at 100 °C Ar for 1 h to remove water from the sample, held at 75 °C for 1 h in a 10 vol% H2/Ar atmosphere, and after cooling down to 30 °C in an Ar atmosphere, the sample is ramped up from 30 °C to 600 °C in an Ar atmosphere in a 5 °C/min program, and hydrogen desorption is detected with a TPD detector. The specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore size of the catalysts are determined using a fully automatic specific surface and porosity analyzer, Micromeritic ASAP 2020. The catalyst samples are treated at 100 °C for 3 h to remove the impurities adsorbed on the surface of the samples. The catalyst samples were pre-piped and degassed for 12 h and then physically adsorbed in liquid nitrogen and the pore size distribution was measured by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns are recorded with a PANalytical Empyrean powder diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα X-ray irradiation source (λ = 0.1541 nm). The working voltage is 45 kV and the working current is 40 mA, and the scanning range is 10° to 80° Hydrogenation tests Hydrogenation reactions were carried out in a 250 mL autoclave under 1.0 MPa H2 pressure at 75 °C and the stirring speed was set at 800 rpm. 0.40 g of catalyst, 14 mL of concentrated sulfuric acid, 0.25 g of hexadecyltrimethylammonium chloride, 126 mL of water, and 25.27 g of nitrobenzene are sequentially added to the reactor. To ensure complete air replacement in the reactor, nitrogen gas at 0.50 MPa is slowly passed into the reactor to replace the air 4–5 times. When the temperature reached 70 ℃, hydrogen gas at 1.0 MPa was introduced, and data were recorded. The operating reaction are as follows: conditions are follows:0.7‒1.0 MPa of hydrogen pressure, 75 °C of reaction temperature and 1000 r/min of stirring rate. The reaction rate is expressed in terms of the consumption of hydrogen gas per unit of time. After the reaction, the liquid product is obtained by vacuum filtration. Subsequently, the liquid product is analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) using an Agilent-1100 instrument. Results and discussion Catalyst characterization The pore structure of the catalyst carbon carriers is analyzed by the N2 physical adsorption-desorption method. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the 3 %Pt/AC‒X sample are shown in Fig. 1a . The effects of different precursors on the catalyst's particle size, specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size are compared. The N2 isothermal adsorption curves of Pt/AC‒X catalysts all showed a type IV isothermal adsorption pattern, indicating that there are abundant micropore structures in the samples [35]. The specific surface area and pore volume of the 3 %Pt/AC‒1 catalyst are 1537 m2/g and 1.10 cm3/g, respectively, which are larger than those of the other samples. This indicates a better dispersion of the metal particles and more exposed active sites in the 3 %Pt/AC‒1 sample [20,23]. The average pore size was around 3.7 nm, suggesting limited influence of size effects on the structure of the activated carbon support. The sample contents are quantitatively and semi-quantitatively analyzed using ICP and EDX, as shown in Table 1 . In all samples, the actual metal content measured by EDX is roughly consistent with the corresponding theoretical values (3wt% Pt loading). The volumetric Pt content measured by ICP is around 3.0 ± 0.05 %, which is consistent with the surface content of 3 % Pt/AC‒X. Similarly, this also indicates a good loading of Pt on the activated carbon. The chemical composition of the samples is investigated through CHNS elemental analysis (Table 1). The samples contained trace amounts of nitrogen, which may be attributed to impurities present in the raw materials. For 3 % Pt/AC‒X, from the XRD pattern (Fig. 1b), it can be observed that all samples exhibited amorphous diffraction peaks of the activated carbon support at approximately 23° and 44° [36,37]. The characteristic diffraction peaks of metallic Pt appeared at 2θ=39.8° for 3 % Pt/AC‒3 and 3 % Pt/AC‒4. However, with the change of precursor, the intensity of Pt characteristic peaks gradually decreased. In 3 % Pt/AC‒1 and 3 % Pt/AC‒2, the Pt characteristic peaks disappeared, indicating that the particles were too small and well dispersed [38,39]. Meanwhile, the particle size of the catalysts is calculated using the Scherrer equation (Eq. (1)) based on the half-width of the characteristic peaks of Pt in the sample (1) d = K λ β cos θ Where K is the shape factor of the grain, taken as 0.89; d is the size of the grain in nm; λ is the wavelength of X-ray, taken as 0.154056 nm; β is the half-width of the diffraction peak; and θ is the diffraction angle in degrees. The calculated results showed that the particle size of 3 %Pt/AC‒3 and 3 %Pt/AC‒4 is 3 nm and 4.5 nm, respectively. Fig. 2 shows the SEM micrograph of 3 %Pt/AC‒X, illustrating the morphology of the material. Low-magnification scanning electron microscope images revealed the overall morphology and internal microstructure of the 3 %Pt/AC‒X sample. It was observed that the crystalline particles of the 3 %Pt/AC‒1 catalyst are roughly spherical, with regular shape, uniform particle size, and good dispersion. The particles of 3 % Pt/AC‒2, 3 %Pt/AC‒3, and 3 %Pt/AC‒4 gradually increased in size, and the dispersion became poorer. This result is consistent with the XRD results. In addition, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and particle size distribution are combined for representative analysis, as shown in Fig. 3 . The metallic nanoparticles of 3 %Pt/AC‒1 are uniformly dispersed on the activated carbon support without significant aggregation, and due to their extremely small size, their particle size could not be determined. The particle size of 3 %Pt/AC‒2 is around 2.5 nm, while the particle size of 3 %Pt/AC‒3 ranged mostly around 3.5 nm, and the average particle size of 3 %Pt/AC‒4 is 4.7 nm. This trend aligns with the XRD results. Therefore, the size and dispersion state of the metallic catalyst nanoparticles have an impact on the catalyst's performance. It is hypothesized that this phenomenon is due to the presence of size effects, which promote the uniform dispersion of Pt nanoparticles. To further support this view, the samples are characterized by IR spectroscopy (Fig. 4 ). It can be observed that the absorption peaks at 1558 cm˗1 and 1200 cm˗1 are specific to 3 % Pt/AC‒X, and as the metallic particle size decreases, there is no significant change in the surface functional groups of the samples [40]. The size effect plays a crucial role in determining the catalytic hydrogenation activity and selectivity. Table 2 summarizes the catalytic performance of various catalysts for the hydrogenation of NB to PAP. Under the effect of different precursors, all catalyst conversion rates of 3 % Pt/AC‒X are above 99 %, which means that nitrobenzene is almost completely converted. The 3 % Pt/AC‒4 catalyst has the shortest reaction time with complete conversion of nitrobenzene, but its selectivity towards aminophenol is 56.7 %. The hydrogen consumption curve (Fig. 5b ) and selectivity graph (Fig. 5a) demonstrate that this catalyst has the fastest hydrogen consumption rate and the highest hydrogen consumption, with a selectivity of 41.0 % towards aniline and 0.5 % towards 4,4′‒diaminodiphenyl ether. This is due to the larger particle size and lower dispersion of Pt. The results show that the scale effect of platinum catalyst has a strong influence on its activity and PAP selectivity. By controlling the Pt particle size, the exposure of Pt increases, and the selectivity of the catalyst gradually improves, reaching as high as 76.4 % towards aminophenol. However, this increased selectivity is accompanied by prolonged reaction time and significantly reduced hydrogen consumption rate. The decrease in particle size and improvement in dispersion effectively suppress the formation of aniline as a byproduct. As the Pt particle size decreases and dispersion improves, the catalyst's adsorption capacity for phenylhydroxylamine weakens, allowing PHA to desorb from the catalyst in a timely manner and undergo rearrangement under acidic conditions to convert to aminophenol. The formation of 4, 4′‒diaminodiphenyl ether is caused by the reaction between aminophenol and phenylhydroxylamine or its bimolecular dehydration. In other words, when evaluating the catalyst in the nitrobenzene-to-aminophenol system, timely cessation of hydrogen after a complete reaction can prevent over-hydrogenation and reduce the formation of 4, 4′‒diaminodiphenyl ether [41,42]. In order to further investigate the electron states of catalyst metal active sites, the XPS analysis method is used to determine the surface electronic state and composition of the synthesized materials. Fig. 6 shows the Pt 4f XPS spectra of 3 %Pt/AC‒X (X = 1, 2, 3, 4). For 3 % Pt/AC‒X, the Pt0 percentage of Pt/AC-X was 63.84 %, 67.46 %, 62.50 % and 68.36 %, respectively. The percentage of Pt2+ was 36.16 %, 32.54 %, 37.50 % and 31.64 %, respectively. The percentages of Pt0 and Pt2+ are irregular. There are two reasons for this situation: Firstly, in the process of sample delivery testing, the waiting time is too long, Pt0 in the sample is oxidized, resulting in Pt2+; Secondly, during the test, the electrons in the X-ray have oxidation properties, which will also lead to an increase in the content of Pt2+. These results show that Pt in Pt/AC exists mainly in reduced form. As the metal particle size decreases, the binding energy of Pt shifts towards lower binding energy, confirming the influence of particle size on the electronic state of Pt. In other words, the particle size can change the electronic structure of Pt, resulting in a rich electron state of Pt sites, which in turn affects the activity and selectivity of the catalyst [43,44]. In the hydrogenation reaction, the rich electron state of Pt can decrease the adsorption energy of active sites for PHA, hindering the excessive hydrogenation of PHA to PAP. It can be inferred that its catalytic activity is not only related to dispersion but also to the electronic state of Pt atoms. TEM, XRD, and XPS results indicate that highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles with high surface Pt° concentration are formed on the activated carbon support, which is the main reason for the enhanced hydrogenation activity of 3 % Pt/AC‒1. The influence of scale effect on the surface hydrogen adsorption behavior of catalysts is studied using H2-TPD. As shown in Fig. 7 , the peak ascriptions are chemical adsorbed hydrogen on the surface of platinum nanoparticles, and the peak intensity is 3 % Pt/AC‒1<3 % Pt/AC‒2<3 % Pt/AC‒3<3 % Pt/AC‒4. Based on the relationship between the adsorption and desorption peak intensities of hydrogen, and the size of each catalyst particle, it can be concluded that as the particle size of the prepared catalyst becomes smaller, the dispersion becomes higher, and the ability to adsorb hydrogen increases, resulting in an increase in the adsorption and desorption of hydrogen [45,46]. This also means that highly dispersed Pt is necessary to promote the transfer of active hydrogen, thereby speeding up the hydrogenation reaction. With the decrease of metal particle size, the adsorption strength of Pt for hydrogen weakens, the dissociation ability of catalytic active sites for hydrogen weakens, and the hydrogen concentration on the catalyst surface relative to decreases. This method effectively reduces the adsorption strength of intermediates generated on the catalyst surface and prevents the excessive hydrogenation of intermediates, leading to the improvement of PAP selectivity. Combined with XPS, the decrease of metal particle size leads to the generation of high-valent Pt, hinders the dissociation of hydrogen in the catalyst, and weakens the ability of the catalyst to adsorb intermediates. The above results are consistent. This indicates that by regulating the metal particle size, the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for intermediates can be affected, resulting in changes in the selectivity of the nitrobenzene selective hydrogenation reaction to aniline. In general, the discovery of this rule has successfully applied to the nitrobenzene selective hydrogenation reaction. The stability of the catalyst is evaluated by selecting the best-performing catalyst, 3 % Pt/AC‒1, for the nitrobenzene selective hydrogenation experiment. The stability and reusability of the 3 % Pt/AC‒1 catalyst were studied. After the reaction, the catalyst is recovered by simple pressure filtration, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 110 ℃. As shown in Fig. 8 and Table S1, after 5 cycles of use, the selectivity and conversion rate of the catalyst is 73.1 % and 98.4 %, respectively. The conversion rate almost remained unchanged, and the selectivity slightly decreased but remained above 73 %. This indicates that the catalyst has high stability [47]. According to the BET characterization results (Table S2), the micropore content of 3 % Pt/AC‒1 is high before the reaction, and after 3 % Pt/AC‒1 is used, the specific surface area, average pore size, and pore volume did not decrease significantly. In addition, the stability of the 3 % Pt/AC‒1 catalyst is further studied using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The results shown in Figure S2 are consistent with the evaluation results. The particle size of the 3 % Pt/AC‒1 catalyst did not change significantly after 5 cycles. These results further confirm the good stability and recyclability of the 3 % Pt/AC‒1 catalyst in the process of nitrobenzene hydrogenation to p-aminophenol. Conclusion In conclusion, platinum-based catalysts with a load-type exhibit size sensitivity in the nitrobenzene hydrogenation reaction, thus exploring the correlation between catalytic performance and particle size. The results show that by changing the platinum precursor, the particle size and dispersion of platinum metal can be adjusted, allowing the catalyst to maintain high conversion rates while demonstrating good selectivity and excellent activity. In addition, the decrease in particle size leads to a decrease in hydrogen concentration on the platinum surface, preventing the over-hydrogenation of intermediates on the catalyst surface to improve reaction selectivity. Characterization results showed that the smaller the catalyst particle size, the more active metal sites are generated, and the larger the contact area with the reaction liquid, thereby increasing reaction activity. The catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity and selectivity even after several cycles, with its structure remaining unchanged. From the experimental data and research results in this study, it can be seen that different metal particle sizes will affect the adsorption rate and product distribution in the nitrobenzene hydrogenation reaction. Our research lays the foundation for future studies on the size effects of different precursors. CRediT authorship contribution statement Feng Feng: Conceptualization. coredata.dc:description: Liquid-phase hydrogenation reaction of nitrobenzene to p-aminophenol (PAP) is investigated using a series of Pt-based catalysts, where activated carbon served as support and ethylene glycol (EG) as the reducing agent and solvent. Different platinum sources are employed to obtain Pt/C catalysts with different Pt metal particle sizes, as determined by transmission electron microscopy. The underlying mechanism of nitrobenzene selective hydrogenation on different size of Pt clusters have been systematically investigated. Characterization and catalytic tests show that the catalytic performance of the Pt-based catalyst is deeply influenced by particle size, where the size around 2.5 nm exhibits a suitable hydrogen absorption and activation ability, leading to the best catalytic performance. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the PAP selectivity reached 76.4 % and the conversion of NB reached 100 %. Moreover, the catalyst displayed strong recyclability with the PAP selectivity remaining above 70 % after five cycles of the catalyst, which would enable promising industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Size control of Pt nanoparticle catalysts for high-selectivity hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to p-aminophenol
